The windows are not rounded at the corners for reasons of drag, as they are already flush with the fuselage of the aircraft. I would recommend looking at the original version of the de Havilland Comet. It had squared off windows, and the focusing of the stress on the windows, due to the repeated pressurization and depressurization of the aircraft led to stress fractures that eventually caused them to fail, causing some high profile accidents. The rounding of the corners significantly reduces that stress, minimizing that risk.

Hi. I love all of your vids. I'd just like to give some constructive feedback. You said plane windows were more oblong to reduce drag, but that could be misleading. As someone who is training to pursue a career in aviation and personally know some aircraft manufacturers, the oblong shape of the windows is more to keep the stress in a roughly continuous path though the fuselage. Basically the rounded edges means that the stress flows more smoothly around the windows avoiding a point of concentrated stress. You were quite correct that the shape reduces the chances of cracking though. I hope you find this useful, and I just want to help make your content as accurate as possible.

The point in 0:21 about gravity is wrong. Gravity barely decreases over that distance. If there was no gravity decrease there would still be a pressure difference. Quite the same as with a pool of water. The real reason why the pressure lowers is because there is simply less air on top of were the plain in flying than when you are on the ground. This reduced amount of air mass above results in a lower pressure.

Furthermore, the main reason the windows are rounded is because this eliminates mechanical weak points at the corners of the windows.The earliest high altitude planes did not have this which resulted in cracks at the corners.

Normally you make good videos, but I'm disappointed that you looked over these points.

The contention at 0:46 that the chances of survival are very slim because of the plane breaking apart is not quite correct; witness UAL 811, which returned safely after such an incident (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Airlines_Flight_811) or even Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aloha_Airlines_Flight_243) which retuned safely after half of its roof was ripped off.

Survivability in such cases is quite high; the people ejected out are usually those who took their seat belts off. This is why I, as a pilot, always announce "I strongly urge you to keep your seat belts on in flight, even if the signs have been switched off". In a few cases, where the entire floor section is ripped away, that's when passengers are sucked out for no fault of their own.

So in short: You will die in the matter of seconds, with a very slim chance of surviving, but the chance of it happening is 1/9821

2 errors - In the event of a depressurisation aircraft will typically descend rapidly to 14,000ft (unless terrain is a factor) where passenger/cabin crew oxy will no longer be needed, however they will stay at that altitude to the limits of the cockpit oxygen (usually hours) then descend further to 10,000ft where they will remain there until destination. - All of this to save fuel. Secondly - There is no control of the electronic locks for the cabin doors in the cockpit. This function is automatic on all modern airliners - The only thing pilots get is a warning if the locks aren't functioning, in which case a cabin crew member will 'guard' the door until differential pressure is enough that the door would be impossible to open.

Windows are basically holes in the skin of the aircraft. Since the plane is pressurized, the skin is stressed as the fuselage expands. Round windows distribute the stress more evenly around them. Square windows cause the stress to build up at the corners, which makes them much more prone to cracks.

0:48 Concentration of O2 at 30,000 ft is almost the same at sea level, 21%. The atmospheric pressure is the problem. O2 diffuses from higher concentration to lower concentration areas. Aka atmosphere to your lungs. This process is driven in part by the difference in pressure between your bloodstream and the atmosphere. At higher altitudes there's less pressure difference to drive the process thus less O2 diffuses into your bloodstream. That's why climbers on Everest have O2 bottles, they can't change the atmospheric pressure so the only solution is to increase the concentration of O2 in the air they breath.
2:16 Airplane windows aren't round because of drag. It's because of stress forces on the fuselage create stress fractures at the corners of square windows leading to structural failures.
1:37 The Airbus A380 doors swing OUTWARDS. Higher pressure on the inside and lower pressure outside make it EASIER to open to door.

less air= less oxygen is NOT accurate. At 30,000 ft the concentration of oxygen is about the same at sea level, 21%. What changes is the partial pressure of oxygen gas. Your lungs absorb oxygen into the blood stream via diffusion. High concentration of oxygen in the air diffuses into your blood stream that has low concentrations of oxygen. This process is driven by the difference in pressure between the atmospheric air and your bloodstream.
At high altitudes you have less atmospheric pressure driving this process. One solution is to increase the concentration of oxygen you are breathing. That's why ppl on Everest carry oxygen bottles. If you are breathing air with a higher concentration of oxygen it compensates for the fact that it diffuses into your bloodstream at a slower rate.

0:50 Less Air does not = Less Oxygen. The higher you are in the atmosphere the lower the Total Air Pressure. The amount of O2 stays the same at roughly 23%. The issue is the since the Total Pressure has dropped so has the Partial Pressure of 02. Anything under about 2.2 psi of 02 Partial Pressure will cause almost immediate blackout. This is due to your lungs being unable uptake 02 because of the lack of Pressure Differential between your lungs and the outside atmosphere.

While that's technically true (at 30 km / 20 miles altitude the force of gravity is 1% lower than at sea level), it's not why pressure is lower at altitude.

Pressure at sea level is higher because all of the layers of air above it are pushing down on it. If the force of gravity was the same at higher altitudes, sea level pressure would actually go up, as those higher layers would press harder.

Great video, but something to consider: Many modern airliners have no electronic locks controlled from the cockpit. However, almost all doors and emergency exits from the cabin are designed in a way that makes in necessary for the door to move into the cabin before it can be swung out. This means that the pressure forces excerted has to be cancelled out before the door can be opened, which is only true when the airplane is on the ground with an open outflow valve (this IS controllable both automatically and manually, of course), or in the event of a cabin pressure loss. Accident history involving pressure loss from holes in the fuselage usually comes from square windows, stress damage to fuselage panels or cargo doors that does not have this "in-before-out" functionality, not the cabin doors. Feel free to yank as hard as you can on any door or emergency exit on your next airliner flight once you are airborne, it won't do anything to the plane (though you might end up in jail).

Hey guys, I love your channel and as an airline pilot, I was excited about what you were going to say... but I was a bit disappointed, you got some facts backwards!

1. aircraft doors cannot be locked from the flight deck. Only the flight deck access door can for security reasons (the part about the huge force required due to pressure is right)
2. the part about everything being sucked outwards is true but a bit overexaggerated. Things in the immediate area might be in danger but the force required would be much larger to empty an entire plane
3. the time and of course oxygen available for a so called emergency descent is more than 10 minutes, it's about 15 minutes for passenger oxygen (which is generated separately from cockpit crew oxygen) and at the very least 15-18 minutes for flight crew.
4. airliners don't fly at 45'000ft, only business jets do.

Couple of things .

1. The windows are not rounded for drag reduction but for better structural integrity , anything with an edge is a weak point as the planes fuselage expands and contracts . Round edges make it difficult for metal fatigue cracks to form.

2. The pilot cannot lock the passenger entry exit doors electronically from the cockpit . Imagine in a crash what would happen if the pilots were unconscious or dead and you couldn’t open the door . The doors are designed to be very easily opened , in fact when armed the doors have a pressurised bottle of co2 to assist in the opening and also inflate the slide to make it easier for people to get out .

That being said it is almost impossible to open them inflight as was rightly said in the video , the doors are plug type kinda like the plug in your bathtub they open inwards first then swing out ,so the differential pressure makes it impossible to open them at altitude .

Happy flying folks .

Windows on planes are not round for aerodynamic purposes, they are round to prevent fatigue at the edges during compression cycles. A plane that used square windows (the Comet) experienced many cases of rapid decompression and mid air breakups due to cracks forming along the edges of the square windows from to the fatigue caused by the expansion and contraction of the airframe when being pressurized and depressurized.

Wow, I'm pretty shocked with the number of errors in this video. Disappointed in a such a large science channel making these easily avoidable mistakes.

1) Air pressure varies with altitude due to the weight of the air pushing down from above. This is why your ears hurt at the bottom of a pool. Not because of increased gravity but because of the weight of the water above you.

2) Airplane windows corners are not rounded to decrease drag! The windows are not in the air stream. They lie flush with the skin of the aircraft and do not create any considerable drag. They are rounded to reduce stress concentrations that form at sharp corners. These concentrations lead to fatigue cracking from the repeated pressurization and depressurization of the aircraft during normal service.

3) This is not technically a mistake but could use more explanation. The door is impossible to open because the way it operates. The door must be pulled into the aircraft slightly then pushed out. You are fighting against the higher pressure on the inside of the door compared to the lower pressure outside. You have to pull against this pressure differential to get the door open.

Tl;dr
Very bad things
False, opening of a door in flight would not cause the plane to break up. Modern fuselages are engineered to handle decompression events such as blowing out a door.

Ok, from 0:23-0:30, no. Thats not how atmospheric pressure works. The gravitational attraction at sea level is only marginally stronger than that in the upper atmosphere. In fact astronauts on the international space station still experience about 90% of the gravitational attraction that we experience on earth. The increased air pressure at sea level is due to a process of hydrostatics, the measure of how pressure increases with depth in a fluid column [in this case a gas]. The best way to understand it simply is to say that the pressure increases, because the molecules lower in the stack have to support the load of the molecules supported above them. The same effect can be observed with water in the ocean or more simple, a swimming pool; the deeper you go the more pressure you feel, for the same reason.

Just a very, very minor nitpick about a minor error in phrasing: When y'all mentioned that airplane windows are rounded to reduce drag, I think you meant to reduce mechanical stresses at the corners. Sharp corners concentrate mechanical stress in the thin aluminum skin of the airframe, and over multiple pressurization cycles, can result in microcracks becoming much larger cracks which becomes explosive decompression. But y'all were correct about the cracks forming part at least.

See also: the DeHavilland Comet.

All in all, good video. :)

I'm skeptical that you would get sucked out of the plane due to the door alone opening (looking aside the possible chance of the hull breaking completely) because there wouldn't seem to be enough mass of air to overcome your inertia in your seat.
Some quick back of the google math says air has a mass of about .08lbs per cubic foot (at STP, ~29 in/hg, only 5 higher than airplane cabin pressure), and that there is approximately 75644 cubic feet of space inside the cabin (a gross over-estimate due to it being a cylinder and not a rectangular box, based on widest, tallest and longest part of the cabin from airbus spec sheet).
On the surface, this looks supportive. That's about 3 tons of air inside the cabin, if it were empty, at STP. If you were standing in front of the door, this would be terrible for you, as the initial burst of pressure decrease would almost certainly carry you out. But, that there are seats, luggage compartments, there is less mass because planes are cylinders (less even, because of luggage space), that an a380 carries 555 passengers (a weight of generally 27 tons, all going for the opening, right?), that pressure differential at cruising altitude is about 20in/hg (though venturi effect would perhaps make it lower) and the fact that the air leaves tangentially to the mass of air in the plane (unless you open the cargo door in a cargo plane) leads me to believe that there isn't enough mass of air to force people out of the plane just because they weren't wearing a seat belt.

Of course, the mythbusters already looked at this (i should have looked there first): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4yG2h1aDB6k Their conclusion seems to support that the plane is unlikely to be rapidly emptied. They didn't test the specific question here, their only real test was if a window disappeared, and even then the person next to the window didn't fit through the window.

These are usually pretty good but there are two sizeable goofs in this one:


First: 0:23 : air is denser near the ground due to hydrostatic pressure from the weight of the air above it. Gravity is not different enough between the surface and the edge of space (~100km up by convention) to cause the massive difference in pressure (2200000x) [2] because that distance is tiny compared to their average distance from the earth's centre of mass (6371km). [1]


Second: 2:10 : windows are rounded to eliminate stress concentrations at corners. This prevents cracks but has nothing to do with drag. They aren't sticking out into the airstream and so can't contribute to drag.



[1] Relevant equations here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton%27s_law_of_universal_gravitation#Gravitational_field
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kármán_line
